reviewText:
I gave this game a shot, I really did. I wanted to like it, and even with it's obvious, glaring flaws, I dug deeper to see if there was something there, but after it was all said and done, there wasn't.

The game presents an interesting idea, and it reminded me of something like Dungeon Keeper. You have dwarves, and you have them mine these caves for you in real-time, collecting resources, which you use to attack the other team. You can find treasures, and different items that give you temporary upgrades for that match, and eventually, one team becomes the victor.
Sound great, right? Well, no, actually.

On paper, the game sounds like it'd be cool, and really fun, but in practice, the controls are just awful. You're forced to move the camera around by clicking and dragging, and issuing commands to your units just feels really cumbersome. The artstyle is interesting for a bit, but once you realize how limited the whole thing is, and how many assets they changed the colors on and re-used. that also begins to lose it's appeal. There is basically no storyline to speak of, and what little bit of flavor text they do try to put in there just comes off as bland and annoying.

I could forgive ALL of these things if the design of the game was fun... but it also fails in that aspect. Nothing I did in the game felt rewarding or satisfying, and I think that's the most damning thing you can say about it. It just feels like a bunch of cumbersome clicking without any payoff. It's a bland, useless, mess of a game, and nobody should waste their time or money with it.

reviewText:
Interesting board game.

Players take turns digging into the field by placing tunnel pieces and then sending their dwarves down to collect as much treasure as possible. Your dwarves can mine for treasure, but that takes time. Larger caches of treasure can be found by killing monsters wandering around the board, although this involves fighting and is much more risky depending on your team makeup. Artifacts are a form of treasure that can have a wide variety of effects, good or ill, and make the game more exciting. The game ends after a certain amount of turns, where the player with the most treasure wins.

It can be quite fun, but for god's sake find a friend to play this with. That is essentially the whole point of a board game, really. And to all of you who bat your eyes at my calling this a board game: you could conceivably convert this to physical form very easily, with a human dungeon master taking the place of the monster AI.

I don't know why all these other reviewers want this game to be something it clearly wasn't supposed to be. I mean, how hard can it be to talk about this game in the way it was designed to be played?

reviewText:
Delve Deeper when I started was at first a simple turn based strategic game.
The toturial in the game is a big dialogue that goes into detail of what the game gives (building tunnels to selecting a dwarf and point it to a tunnel where he can mine gold).

The game resolve where you can play from 2  to 4 players and the game is decided by how much gold you have earned through mining gold, gem, mithril, loot and relics.
(To play multiplayer. You need to play it on the computer the game is on. Meaning you can't play from over the world. (Which is actually a must for a game like this).

Before you start you can choose to three classes:
- Miner:
This class can hold up to 6 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can walk 4 steps and is overall the points getter in the game.
- Fighter
This class can hold up to 4 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can only walk 3 steps and is overall the one who protect and fight
- Scout
This class can only hold up to 3 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can walk 6 steps and is overall the one to kill weak monsters and light tunnels that is farther away.

The relics in this game make said classes stronger, but said relic will only have effect on the said dwarf who picked said relic up.
Relics can be turned in at bazaars or the camp (where you start) and might give favourable effects that will last the whole game.
(Relics also have some references to pop culture, Dwarf Side of the Moon as an example).

The enemies in the game (monsters/players) make the game a little more strategic as well with building tunnels.
Building tunnels is optional. you can use it to progress deeper in the mine or give it an opening for monsters to attack other players. Making the gameplay a little more fun. Tunnels is at first dark, but everytime you or the other player/computer goes to a dark tunnel. the dwarf will light the tunnel up preventing spawning for more monsters.

Every map have it's set amount of rounds that varies. (creating a map will give automatically an amount of rounds).
making you're own map is at first a great feature. Only that you need every hex to be filled to make it truelly playable.
Picking out tunnels without showing what pieces you can select (picking a wrong piece meaning you need to click said hex to redo it). You will be taking a lot of time to create a map. since it's a lot of trials and errors.

Overall it's a solid game and maybe a must for all strategic gamers out there.
But for me I can't recommend this game.

Pros:
- Easy, Fun Gameplay
- Strategic to it's core

Cons:
- Slow Gameplay
- Creating a map is (kinda) frustrating
- Multiplayer is local-only

Feedback for this review is appreciated.

Delve Deeper is a game about dwarven greed. But mostly TREASURE! Go down there and grab as much as you can for your most exhalted king. And more importantly, get more than the other teams!

You'll go in with five(5) dwarves, and will need to collect as much loot as you can in games that seem to go by pretty quickly. It's a good game to start up when you're bored or don't know what else to play, or just because you want to grab some more of that sweet gold.

Of your team, you can select 3 classes. The slow, powerful fighters. Fast, but slightly weak scouts, and miners who are a bit average at everything but can haul the most loot. Of course, being dwarves, all classes can mine gold, gems and mithril and carry chests of loot out, but some can carry more than others, and some fight better than others.
And since you are trying to prove you are more loyal to your king and better at extracting riches, you may end up fighting the other dwarven teams as well.

It's a simple game with solid mechanics, where you start your turn with a tunnel piece you can put down somewhere to expand your tunnels, or to unleash a massive horde of goblins into your opponent's tunnels. After that, you move your dwarves and end your turn. After that you fight with whichever dwarves are in tiles with enemies on them. A simple and easy to learn system with plenty of maps and plenty of replayability. And on top of that, it's cheap too

Worth grabbing whenever you have some cash left over for it. It's cheap, amusing to play, has plenty of replayability(So long as you don't play it all the time) and a most worthy king to deliver all your gold to who occasionally comments on things going on in his own special kind of way.

The page on this includes RPG and adventure in the description, but don't be fooled -- it's purely turn-based strategy.  You play on a variety of 2d side scrolling maps which each have a set number of turns for you to find and return the most loot for the dwarf king.  Maps are grid-based and you get to dig one grid deeper each turn.

You play as a team of five dwaves taking turns against 1-3 other teams.  You can choose a combination of scouts, miners and fighters to compose your team.  They all have different pros and cons: miners can carry more loot, but are weak to enemies and other players; scouts can move more grid spaces each turn, but are also weak; fighters can take down enemies but move fewer spaces and carry less.  Loot is either mined, dropped off slain enemies/players or found as artifacts laying around.  You must use a turn to deposit them at certain grids on the map before they count toward your score.

Plenty of achievements, settings, looks nice and is fun.

reviewText:
Delve Deeper is a game which on the surface seems cute and innocent.  However, below the exterior is a game which is deceptively difficult and unendingly fun.

Is the ultimate goal is to make more money for your king than the other team.  You will need to excavate tunnels in order to get at the wealth which is hidden from view.  Where will you dig your tunnels, and what strategy will you use when placing them in order to find the greatest amount of wealth?

There are all manner of nasty things down there which are just waiting to be released so that they can attack your Miners.  Usually they guard large amounts of wealth or the entryways two areas which you need in order to be able to, of course, delve deeper which is where the best of the loot is to be found.  The questions here are, do you risk the attack, and if you do, how many of your Miners will you commit to the battle?  Your Miners can't be killed, but they can get beat up so badly that they will miss the next turn.  That can end up in the cycle where your miner is being killed every turn and therefore cannot mine or escape on tell a group of his compatriots com to his rescue and defeat the monster.  In this instance your Miners are spending their time rescuing, and not mining, whilst your competitor is merrily running up the score in his favour.

Then there are chests.  Chests are gamble.  They can give you a huge advantage, give you a huge disadvantage, attack you (because they aren't really chests but rather monsters in disguise), or they can be worthless old tat.  Will you risk picking it up?  If it doesn't attack, you will need to carry it some distance to turn it in either at the surface or at a turn in location which you have discovered somewhere in your mine.

There is much more to this game than what I have discussed thus far, but hopefully this will give you some feeling for the complexities as you play this game and plan your strategies.  As I stated in the beginning, it is deceptive, and there is much more to it than immediately meets the eye.  If you buy this game (an excellent value for money at the usual price and even better when it's on sale) then I wish you many hours of fun just as I have had, delving deeper!

The premise is simple. You build a team of dwarves that dig, collect and fight in a mine to collect the most treasure at the end of a certain number of rounds. You play against other teams of AI or local co-op if you can find someone else who wants to play this game. For the most part it's a strategy game with some RPG elements. Other than directing your team where to mine you don't have much control other than that.

The fighting parts are played completely by the AI. There are difficulty settings you can adjust but for the most part the other dwarf teams will just try and mine more than you and the random monsters will attack the closest group to them. Another thing about the monsters is that some are also randomly generated during the match. So while you might only see 4 or 5 near you during their turn can quickly spawn an extra 10. This is annoying as you're pretty much screwed when you only have a team of 5 at most and if they aren't 5 fighters you will die rather quick and the monsters will just attack you again the moment you get back up.

Ironically the only reason you'd want to play this game is to mine achievements. There's plenty to be had some harder to achieve than others. There's a good variety of maps and even the option to create your own. This game has potential to be very good but overall an average party mining game but low on the list of games I'd want to play with others.

reviewText:
Maybe it's the beard talking, but I've always liked dwarves more than elves. They don't care about harmonizing with trees and developing anorexia. They're a race of hairy, pudgy alcoholics, and if there's anything in fantasy lore I can relate to, it's going to be that.

Delve Deeper(!) is a strategy game about mining. You command a team of five dwarves as they try to collect more treasure than any other team and win their king's praise. Each turn begins by placing a piece of tunnel into one of the unoccupied hexagons on the map to reveal any treasure within and build paths to yet more treasure (or to connect tunnels containing monsters to opposing teams' tunnels for your amusement and possible gain).

Next, the dwarves are moved. Once a player ends their turn, that team's dwarves hang lanterns where they stand (as in Minecraft, light prevents monsters from spawning), and mine any nearby treasure, fight any nearby enemies, heal, or drop their treasure off, depending on what occupies the space alongside them.

Delve Deeper has a pretty good sense of humor, most often taking the form of the Dwarven King's reactions to the dwarves' success or lack thereof. There's referential humor as well, but it thankfully doesn't feel as though it's being used as a crutch, as referential humor so often is.

The gameplay is tactical, but easy to learn and most certainly fun. Everything from AI difficulty to monster and treasure frequency can be set to meet the player's needs. Aesthetically, the game is quite charming, considering it features a bunch of hairy, pudgy alcoholics. At $5, Delve Deeper is definitely worth a shot.

reviewText:
Delve Deeper is a light, entertaining turn-based strategy game in which each player commands a team of five dwarves in a race to gather as much gold and jewels as possible within the time limit.

The rules are simple and straightforward, and the experience feels a lot like a board game as it plays out. Each turn, you will place a new section of tunnel, move each of your dwarves, and then watch as they fight monsters and gather treasure. Battles are basic RPG fare, and are handled automatically.

The strategy elements come into play as you decide how to task your dwarves. Each dwarf can only hold a fixed amount of treasure, which must be returned to your base camp (or to a gnomish bank, for a fee) in order to be added to your score. There are also special relics which can be collected; these remain a mystery until they are turned in at camp, at which time they may give you a large boost in your treasure, provide the dwarf who was carrying it a boost to life, attack power, or speed, or even *subtract* points from your score in the case of cursed items.

Strategic placement of tunnels is also important. The layouts of tunnels that may be placed become more restricted as you move from the highest 'dirt' level down through the 'stone' layer and into the 'deep'. If placing tiles carelessly, you might find yourself unable to reach a treasure-laden tunnel in the future. You also have the option of connecting monster-filled tunnels to your opponent's tunnel system in order to distract and delay them.

I played several games of Delve Deeper against the CPU, each of which took 45-60 minutes to play out. I didn't see any way to save my progress during a game; all of the games I played were completed in a single session, but the lack of saving did discourage me from trying some of the larger maps.

Positives:
* Quick and easy gameplay provides bite-sized strategy without a major time commitment
* Charming 16-bit-esque visuals and humorous writing

Negatives:
* No save functionality
* A button to fast-forward through the computer's turn would have been nice

reviewText:
This game would have been a better board game than a video game.

It's you versus the enemy (or other players), and your goal is to gain the most treasure by the end of the game. The deeper you go, the better the loot. The game moves too slow to play for 5 or 10 minutes, but it ends too quickly to be satisfying.

Playing against the computer, I found myself trying to use a strategy of digging as deep as I can to get the best kind of loot. But there's too much randomness in the loot, that I found myself losing really bad. And it's not the choices you make either. Sometimes, you bring up a treasure chest and it had a bomb in there, so you lose 5 gold. And sometimes, your opponent brings up a treasure chest, and it had 10 gold. Not fair.

This is the Monopoly of video games. Fun idea, but throw strategy out of the window.

If the devs could add some more depth with maybe a patch or some dlc then the game may be quite good as they have a very solid base to build a great game. Until then though, I can't recommend anyone this game.

Delve Deeper

With turn-based strategies not being as popular as it's counter part, Delve Deeper takes a quick and humorous drive into the treasures of the deep caves. Play as a Dwarf mining team to dig, fight and cash in as quickly as possible.

Pro - Fun and easy, simple art design, humorous dialog, light RPG elements.

Con - Maps can be too small or too big, AI can snow ball on you really fast, AI moves units one at a time taking forever for one turn.

Verdict - Buy it, it's cheep and really fun. It's good if you have a turn-based strategy itch that needs to be scratched.

Delve Deeper basically plays out like a board game in a mine-digging setting that somehow proved to be extremely popular a couple of years ago (the setting, not the game).

However, I never had a chance to play with other people, leaving me with nothing but skirmishes against NPCs. There is no kind of story campaign and as such it just not engaging to play on your own, which is a pity considering how dead of a game it is.
